markdownRemark.html:
GatsbyJS has been exploding over the static JS scene over the last few months. Developers everywhere are embracing Gatsby for it‚Äôs ability to simplify static content generation, as well as it‚Äôs content and asset aggregation through GraphQL. They make it much easier to spin up a new project and build blazing fast static React apps. It‚Äôs become my go-to when working with any static site, such as landing pages or blogs, where content isn‚Äôt very dynamic and benefits from preprocessing.

As great as GatsbyJS is, it can take a while to start your first project. You have to download and install their CLI, bootstrap a new project with npx, or clone a starter project repo. Then you can spin up the local dev environment. It‚Äôs not a lot, but it is a commitment, particularly when you‚Äôre introducing it to someone new. You want results, and fast.

Blazing fast sites ‚Äî in a blast üí£üî•

What if you could just click a link, wait for dependencies to download and compile, and blam ‚Äî you‚Äôve got yourself a Gatsby blog? This is the kind of world we live in thanks to platforms like CodeSandbox.

But this got me thinking, why not use CodeSandbox as a kind of CMS for your blog? Since it works off Github, and can commit code/pull requests, you‚Äôre capable of editing and authoring any content you‚Äôd like (as long as it‚Äôs static - like Markdown or JSON). Just open up the Sandbox, create a new Markdown file, make a pull request, and you‚Äôre done! (depending on your build process)

How it works ‚öôÔ∏è

CodeSandbox added server-side platforms like Gatsby, Node, and Apollo a few months ago. This allows anyone to spin up (any?) Gatsby project in your browser. If you don‚Äôt already have a Gatsby blog, there‚Äôs no excuse now.

Only requirements?

  • Github account
  • CodeSandbox account (uses Sign-in with Github)

Here‚Äôs how it roughly works:

  • Pick a Gatsby starter template that pulls content locally (like text, markdown, MDX, etc)
  • Open on CodeSandbox. You can open any Github repo by using the format codesandbox.io/s/githubuser/reponame/
  • Create a new page or content file (like MDX). In Gatsby, any React component in the /src/pages/ directory will be a page. For content sites (like Markdown), try finding an example .MD post to copy.
  • Fork sandbox (click button on top or happens automatically when you save changes).
  • Save new repo to Github. Click the Github icon on the left side, sign in using Github, and save the repo there.
  • Save any changes and commit code (if not already)
  • Merge pull request on Github
  • Use a service like Netlify to build your code.

You could build Gatsby locally on your machine, but this tutorial assumes you‚Äôre trying to achieve everything in the cloud.

You could also use Netlify CMS once you‚Äôre using Netlify. However, you don‚Äôt get the same benefits of the ‚Äúlocal dev environment‚Äù that CodeSandbox emulates, like a live preview, editing React components, or Gatsby configs.

Deploying with Netlify üöÄ

  1. Sign up for a Netlify account
  2. Create a new site from Git

Netlify should automatically detect Gatsby and run the appropriate build script. If not (or if you have a custom/pre-build script), you can change it in the Netlify deploy settings.

Caveats üêõ

The only tiny bug I‚Äôve encountered involves using MDX with Gatsby (ironically the starter I chose to feature as well). When you save an MDX file, the changes don‚Äôt immediately propogate in the live preview.

The way MDX works is by compiling static assets like JS files for all the JSX components you import, then Gatsby displays those. Every time you save, new static assets are generated for any changed MDX file (instead of using hot module reloading like most CLIs).

This gets a little clunky in CodeSandbox, and sometimes you won‚Äôt see changes immediately (requring a refresh of the live preview window).

Why stop at blogs? üë®‚Äçüíª

If you need to whip out a fast static website completely in the cloud, this is your solution. This streamlines the design sprint: allowing you to jump directly into code that easily shareable with collaborators, synced with Git, and effortlessly iterable through forks. Whether you‚Äôre working on a landing page or a deck for your next conf talk, Gatsby has plenty of starters to get you hacking away even faster üëç And combined with services like Netlify that deploy from Git repositories, your workflow can‚Äôt get any faster (or secure!).

And if you haven‚Äôt already explored CodeSandbox, I highly suggest checking it out. It‚Äôs a really useful tool not only for coding from scratch, but also pulling up any git branch, which makes it fantastic for creating examples or reviewing PRs live. Also deploys to Zeit‚Äôs Now if you‚Äôre into that ‚ñ≤ üåö

Hope this helps! Ryo

References:

  • CodeSandbox
  • GatsbyJS
  • GatsbyJS Starters
  • Gatsby Starter - MDX + PrismJS + Styled Components + TS
  • Deploying GatsbyJS to Github Pages
  • Netlify
